titleStmt.title: A prospective for King and subjects. Or A schort discovery of some treacheries acted against Charles the I. and Charles the II. Kings of England, Scotland, and Ireland. With some few advertisements to the people in the 3. nations concerning the cruel, exorbitant, and most tyrannical slavery they are now under which they have wrought themselves into, and stil desiring to be, by up-holding of a pretended court of Parliament, altogether ruling contrary to the lawes of the lands or any branch there of and according to there owne lustful and arbitrary wills. Written by Wendy Oxford once an honourer of them and there pretences, but now as great an abhorrer of there Macheeslian practises.
titleStmt.author: Oxford, Wendy.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

With Some few adverti≈øements to the people in the 3. Nations concerning the cruel, exorbitant, and mo≈øt Tyrannical ≈ølavery they are now under which they have wrought them≈øelves into, and ≈øtil de≈øiring to be, by upholding of a pretended court of Parliament, altogether ruling contrary to the Lawes of the Lands or any branch there of, and according to there owne Lu≈øtful and arbitrary wills.

div.q: Let St. Pauls Epi≈øtle to the Romanes, be now judge again≈øt ≈øuch Antichri≈øtian Romancing Rulers, as are a≈ø≈øembled together at We≈øtmin≈øter.
Romanes 1. Chapt. and the 24. and 25. ver≈øes. Wherefore God gave them up to unclea≈ø≈øene≈ø≈øe, and to the change the truth into alie, worshipping the creature more then the creatour.

div.head: To the Mo≈øt High and Mighty ≈øufferer of this age Charles the II. by the grace of God, Right and true Borne King of England, Scotland, and Ireland.
div.p:
BEfore I begge your ≈øacred Maje≈øtyes patronizing this mite, which shal be conneighed into your natur all ≈øoyles, for as wel correction to your enemies, as al≈øo the cherishing of the ≈øtarvinge and dying people therein, who have layd long greived and langui≈øhing under an arbitrary power. I be≈øeech you to remember the advice given to your royal Father of ble≈ø≈øed memory by a wi≈øe man. Make not knowne the cheife≈øt of your determinations to an open councell (al though≈øtyled a privy councel) lea≈øt you faile in the di≈øigne, vera, amicitia, tantum modo e≈øt inter bonos mali nec inter≈øe amici ≈øunt, nec cum bonis, Neither doe any thing of great concernmeÃÑt in councel of a civil freind, in vvhich your Maje≈øty cannot be ≈øafe in the execution thereof unle≈ø≈øe it be concealed: Civilem amicum ≈øic habeas ut putes po≈ø≈øe in imic√∫m fieri. Admire not (Gracious Sr.) that in a corner of the earth I vvhi≈øper this councel unto you, for had your ≈øacred Father beleived the ≈øame he had never beene ≈øo unhappy as to be murthered by his ovvne people (nay by ≈øom of tho≈øe he made his bo≈øome freinds) and con≈øequently your royal ≈øelfe had not beene expo≈øed to ≈øuch termes as your ovvne ≈øoule, better knovves then any. But
vincit qui patitur. No I vvrit this ≈ømal en≈øueing treati≈øe unto your Maje≈øty that you may have an in≈øight of vvhat you haue done, and the better you vval di≈øcerne vvhat is to be done, by remooving al ≈øychophauts vvho lay par≈øonally in the brea≈øt of your Fathers and your Maje≈øtyes, but there harts in the trea≈øury of both your knovvne enemies. Latet anguis in herba! and ≈øtil the ≈øeeds of tho≈øe adamites are ingendring in your councels which (gracious Prince) I hold my ≈øelfe bound induty to make knowne to your Maje≈øty, & thereby give a caveat to you for the future, ≈øeing the glory of God & the good of my Soveraigne, and 3 commonwalths at ≈øtake If your Maje≈øty ≈øhould di≈øcountenance the worke, my comfort remaines that the frowe of my Prince may turne to the favour of my God nec mendacii utilitas e≈øt diuturna, nec veritatis damnum diu nocet, neither ≈øhal flattery ≈øtil hold in credit, nor truth alway continue in di≈øgrace. No no (Great Sr.) none but ≈øuch as joyne with your Enemies (knowing you to be Heire apparent of ≈øo great a monarch (who was not only defender of the faith, but martyre thereof) dares be tacite (e≈øpecially) when the chri≈øtian fayth lyes wallowing in the blood of its owne ≈øaints over the whole earth in your Maje≈øteys being ≈øo unlawfully kept from that Scepter, which u≈øvally did protect the innocent, and detect the nocent: which that it may once more be put in the hand of your righteous ≈øelfe the vicegerent of the Lords, I here on my bended knees offer unto the mo≈øt high my humble≈øt praiers for your Maje≈øtyes ≈øafety, and in throning (not doubting but your gracious goodne≈ø≈øe will grant protection to the≈øe my de≈øires) and that as dayes
multiplies on your haires and yeares on your people, that the wei≈ødome of God and ≈øavour of your owne ≈øubjects may be joyned with the helpe of al chri≈øtian princes (making it there owne ca≈øes) to the re≈øtablishing of your Maje≈øtyes 3. Crownes. This ≈øuit wil I never give ouer, in al others, I wil remaine

closer.signed: Your Maje≈øtyes faythful and obedient ≈øubject during lyfe. Wendy Oxford.

div.head: The Epistle to every free borne ≈øubject of England, Scotland, and Ireland.
div.p: I De≈øire not to hold thee long in the porche, but intreat thee to enter into the hou≈øe, where if thou finde≈øt any thing which thou can≈øt cal thine, I pray take it, and of the re≈øt, if there be any thing which may doe thee good in the time of peace or warre, tribulation or pro≈øperity, accept thereof, but as thou reade≈øt it, I begge of thee to ob≈øerve wel, and be an impaitiall judge of the truth thereof, which if thou bee≈øt there in re≈øolved, doe not only of (what is true) lay up, where theeves may breake through and ≈øteale it away, but lay the good ≈øo up, that thou Maje≈øt (upon a good opportunity) make good u≈øe thereof to the freeing thy ≈øelfe from the thraldome thou art under, and the darkne≈ø≈øe of thy Salvation thou art kept in by tho≈øe who made the glory of God, and thy freedome from Tyranny, there pretences, & ≈øtalking hor≈øes, but they rule notouer you as chri≈øtians or as the beloved of the Lord but as Servants forcing you to make bricke without ≈øtraw. Which that you may be freed from, by a mo≈øt Faythfull Mo≈øes, ≈øhalbe the harty praiers and wel wishis of

closer.signed: Thy loving countryman and Brother in Chri≈øt. Wendy Oxford.

div.head: A Pro≈øpective for KING AND SVBIECTS.
div.p:
I Have read of William Rufus a King of England was ≈ølaine with an arrow Shotte at a hart by a knight, and in an other Hi≈øtory I find that Ba≈øilius Macedo A Romaine Emperour was killed with the ≈øtroake of a hart in hunting, Cajus and Fulvius Valerius Ana≈øta≈øius (wee read al≈øo) the Emperours peri≈øhed by lightning, as al≈øo young Dru≈øus Pompey the Sonne of the Emperour Claudius was choaked with a peare which he ca≈øt up and caught it in his mouth in a ≈øportiue way, ≈øo likewi≈øe of Charles King of Navarre wee read he came to a ≈øtrange and untimely death, for he being ≈øewed up in a ≈øheet by night that he might be bathed in it, he that ≈øeued it, went to burne of the thread with the candle, and ≈øet fire on the ≈øheet, ≈øo that the King being ≈øo much ≈øcorched with the heat, died threon in three dayes. You may likewi≈øe read of Euripiudes of very great fame who was unawares torne to peeces by doggs and (as plyny writeth) An acreon was choaked with the ≈øtone of a Ray≈øin, and Marius with a haire in a me≈ø≈øe of milke, yea I read of Plinie him≈øelfs peri≈øhed by a ≈øtronge fire of mount Veve≈øus Whil≈øt he was ≈øeeking to know the rea≈øon thereof, ≈øome ends there lives in laughing as Valerius Maximus, others by ≈øneezing, and as I began with a King of England I wil end with a King of England, whom weread was buggered with a hot ≈øpitt
through a horne into his fundament up into his body, but this was a cruel act of privacy, but never did you read or heare of any Prince or King murthered after ≈øuch a manner as Charles the I. was on the 30. day of Ianu. 1648. about 2. of the clocke in the afternoone, niether did I ever heare or read of any Kings or princes ≈øo much laid ≈ønares for & ≈øo much betrayd as there have beene together, vide: King Iames, King Charles the I. and King Charles the II. And if you wil force me to beleive there hath, I mu≈øt confe≈ø≈øe there hath beene tracheries, which haue beene acted again≈øt Kings, and Princes, but ≈øtil have beene di≈øcovered, before execution, as Cae≈øar who≈øe life was taken from him as he was goeing to the ≈øenate hou≈øe; yet it was di≈øcovered to him in a letter before, if he had read it, to have beleeved it; ≈øo, many plotts there was again≈øt the late Queene Eli≈øabeth, ≈øome dangerous ons again≈øt King Iames, but put them altogether, they reach not at the throngs of treacheries, in this our age. For the cheife≈øt of your Royal Fathers Nobility, (Dread Soveraigne) and gentry, nay whom he made Noble, and whom he pre≈øerved from peri≈øhing, nay let mee goe higher; ≈øome, whom he (by his gracious goodne≈ø≈øe) redeemed from death, which they were condemned unto by Iu≈øtice for trea≈øon again≈øt him ≈øelfe, and others formurther; The≈øe very people being cho≈øen councellours to him, not only betrayed him from there very beginning of there tru≈øts repo≈øed in them, as to the loo≈øing his peoples harts, but al≈øo in the renting his Kingdomes, and al the territories thereunto belonging from him and his po≈øterity, nay not re≈øting there, but in the conclu≈øion (ca≈øting of the name of treachery) they pre≈øumed to take away his life, under the colour of Iu≈øtice by a Pylate and phari≈øaical judges openly to condemne him in the ≈øame Hal, whre they ≈øhould ju≈øtly haue died formerly, and then executed there cruel murther on him at the gates of his owne court, and ona≈øcaffold openly in the face of his owne people, as if he had
beene a traitor to him≈øelfe, nay they cutt his ≈øacred life of in the mo≈øt ignominous way that could be inmagined, even as the greate≈øt traitor that ever was ≈øince England received chri≈øtrianty even by the hand of the common Hangman belonging to Tyburne. O prodigious Mon≈øters? who≈øe per≈øons and actions ≈øhalbe ≈øome what laid forth in this booke, when I come to my advi≈øe to the poore blinded people: but they are more at large painted out to the life in my booke intituled. The bani≈ø hed mans complaint comming forth.

Should I begin at the ≈øu≈øt of King Iames, and ≈øo de≈øcend to this very day of al the treacheries which have beene acted at home in councels, and a broad again≈øt the States of the 3. Kingdomes, I ≈øhould be in a laborinth, and weary the readers patience, wherefore I wil but cull out ≈øome remarkable ons, and indeed but poynt at ≈øome of them, enough for for your gracious Maje≈øty to per≈øeive what is meant in the whole.

Did not your royal Father of Ble≈ø≈øed memory (al though ≈øo cru≈øified by his owne ≈øubjects) put his whole tru≈øt of the managing, the whole affaires of his Kingdomes in to the hands of his councel: and was he not betrayed (before ever a Parliament was called) by ≈øome of them, ≈øworne privy councellers, was it not plainely ≈øeene that there was a Spani≈øh pur≈øe alwaies open a mong≈øt them, was not the Spani≈øh faction moulded ≈øo high with the riches of the Indies, that never ≈øince Queene Elizabeth died, revenge could be endeavoured again≈øt the in≈øolent but ≈øubtile Spaniard. And was not there a French pox in other ≈øome of his councellours cau≈øing a rottenne≈ø≈øe in there harts, to the Keeping his then Maie≈øty from maiking warres & regaining the lo≈øt claime of that Crowne, and when at la≈øt, ≈øome more hone≈øt then the re≈øt did per≈øwade an army to be≈øent over, did not then golden french Pi≈øtols (by treacheary) overcome the Engli≈øh Steele, who≈øe edge formerly was a terrour to al nations
And with leave (Great Prince) was not your royal Father betrayed in al his privy councels, councels of warre, and in his very bedchamber at Yorke, Shrewsbury and Oxford, was there ever any thing of con≈øiquence, acted there in, nay but ≈øpoke on, or was ever de≈øigne but intended on his Enemies in the field, or upon any Garri≈øon, but it was pre≈øently ≈øent away to the General, or Scontma≈øter General of his Enimies, or to the Commander in cheife, of the next Gari≈øon of Enemies, or if time would premit to the committy of ≈øafety, then ≈øitting at Darby Hou≈øe, was it not that your Fathers Enimies there trea≈øury was greater then his (they having the revenues of al his, the Royal Queenes, & your then Princely ≈øelfe with your Brothers the Duke of Yorke, and mo≈øt of al the nobility and greate≈øt gentery in the whole Kingdome, be≈øides there dayly a≈ø≈øe≈øments and loanes, and ≈øub≈øidies with many other extraordinary taxes, as exci≈øes of al things, together with the infinite and va≈øt ≈øummes of monyes rai≈øed on Bi≈øhops, Deanes and chapters lauds, enough to purha≈øe whole Armyes, Townes, and Cities, as in conclu≈øion they did, for were not thereby whole Armyes, Cities, Gari≈øons of Townes, and Forts ≈øold to his then Maie≈øtyes, and now continuing yours; are not the proverbes too too much veryfied in the≈øe latterdayes. Monyes makes the mare to goe: and an a≈ø≈øe laden with gold ≈øhal enter in to the ≈øtronge≈øt city or towne what ever, and the golden Key unlocke the ≈øtronge≈øt gates that are, yes, your Mai≈øty ≈øees and feeles the truth hereof. For no ≈øooner was the ≈øacred life of your deare Father and our ≈øoveraigne taken away, but immediatly me≈ø≈øages weere ≈øent to ≈øome about your ≈øacred ≈øelfe for the holding of corre≈øpondency with them at We≈øtmin≈øter which the very bu≈øine≈ø≈øe of Bredah ≈øpeakes ≈øomething thereof, for no ≈øooner was anything done (altough never ≈øo privatly thought) but with in 3. dayes the whole re≈øult was at Whitehal (that once a royal ≈øeat for our Kings and
Queenes but now a denne of thieves) which would have beene made good to your Maie≈øty by ≈øome what wi≈øhed happine≈ø≈øe to you at the hague, but truth was cru≈ø≈øhed in the ≈øhel, and tho≈øe bla≈øted for there good intentions: But pardon mee (Gracious Sr.) that I am ≈øo plaine, I mo≈øt humbly be≈øeech your gracious Maje≈øty. I mu≈øt now goe a long with your Maie≈øtyes councellours from Bredah into Schotland, from whence I mu≈øt tel your gracious goodne≈ø≈øe there was dayly po≈øtings betweene ≈øome of your chrife≈øt pretended friends and your opene≈øt Enemies, (O Sr.) there have proceeded a world of teacheries, as fir≈øt concerning the holding your Maie≈øty from taking the Covenant until your thro at was ready to be, cut the ≈øteele of your Enimies being thereby prepared, tho≈øe treacherous vermins that put triphles into your conceience were hired thereunto, for that your Enimies knew, the ≈øchotts nation would not tru≈øt you nor fight for you, until you had done it, and al≈øo the≈øcotts, Iuncto would not doe there ut mo≈øt in rai≈øing of an Army until they had your con≈øcience engaged, which was too late, when you had taken it, for by that time, your Enimies became ma≈øters of the field. Next looke upon that mo≈øt traiterous act of delivering up of Edenburgh, Ca≈øtle and Leith, was not 20000. paid downe for it and the Governour thereof now the only man with your Enemies, then was it not a ≈øylver bridge that conveyed your Enemies over in to Fife, did not the ≈øilver ore quench the heat of Brent I laud, and ≈øo al along in your Maie≈øtyes whole progre≈ø≈øe in Scotland, to be ≈øhort hath not monyes conquered al Scotland.

Now (mo≈øt ≈øuffering Prince) give mee leave to march a long with your councellours from ≈øterling into England, where they layd the plott your Maie≈øtye ≈øhould be katched in a trappe, to that end you were ≈øu≈ø≈øered to goe without let or mole≈øtation, your Enemies being a≈ø≈øured before hand, that you ≈øhould not march to London, where you had fini≈øhed
your de≈øines. What was it but monyes that hindered you from ≈øuffering the gallant Cavalery under the Duke of Bucks, earle of Cleveland, and Ma≈ø≈øy, to fal on your Enemies at Torwood where God had de≈øigned there for your prey had you not beene betrayed. What was it but monyes that when your Maie≈øty was advi≈øed by ≈øome of your mu≈øt faithful ≈øubjects to march immediatly to London, that you were advi≈øed too lay downe before Carlile a daye & night, on ≈øet purpo≈øe that Lambert and Harri≈øon Major Generals of 2. brigades of your enemies, hor≈øe might be joyned together, and that Cromwel General of your enemies might come up in the reare of your army who was at lea≈øt 9. dayes march from you, yes, it was monyes that did al this, and tho≈øe very per≈øons that received it now lye in pri≈øon for a colour, but ≈øpend after that extraordinary manner, as if they were more then free ≈øubjects. Againe was it not 30000. paid to ≈øome appoynted to receive it, that cau≈øed David Le≈øly (when as your Maje≈øty had given the Duke of Bucks and that gallant gentleman Ma≈ø≈øy 500. hor≈øe to goe a part from your army, and when the Duke ≈øent for 500. hor≈øe more with the harty de≈øire of doeing ≈øome acceptable peece of ≈øervice in breaking an a≈ø≈øociated committee of Traitors met from divers counties for the rai≈øing forces again≈øt your Maje≈øty, which the ≈øaid Duke might ea≈øily have taken and di≈øper≈øed them every on had his grace had the 500. hor≈øe ≈øent for) what was it cau≈øed David Le≈øly to come unto your Maje≈øty and tel you that the Duke was a young ≈øouldier, and would engage your whole army, and ≈øo cau≈øe a lo≈ø≈øe of al pre≈øently (which he by a lingring way lo≈øt in the end) which cau≈øed your Maje≈øty immediatly to ≈øend an expre≈ø≈øe order under your owne hand & ≈øeale for the calling backe the Dake of Bucks to your body: and what was it but a Sylver barre that cro≈ø≈øed your rode to London, and what was it that when your army had the bal at there ‚Ä¢ eet at waring
ton Bridge and your enemies Lambert and Harni≈øon at the mercy of your army, that they were ≈øuffered to goe a way untouched, nay ≈øuffering many faithful and gallant gentlemen (who were on the for lorne hope) to be taken and caryed away pri≈øoners within le≈ø≈øe then mu≈øket ≈øhort of your whole army, and but by a ≈ømal party of the enemy, yet not relea≈øed by your Generals command but contrary command given that none ≈øhould ≈øtirre. Next let mee remind your faced ≈øelfe of the many treachirous acts at Worce≈øter, as fir≈øt the advice of being drawne to that place of no ≈øtrength, to be taken in a nett as a covey of partridges: Secondly when as halfe of the army of your enemies were marched under the command of L. General Fleet wood by up ton over the bridge and ≈øo came clo≈øe to the other ≈øide Worce≈øter, which is in compa≈ø≈øe 18. Kingdomes, O Sir, it was not for want of courage

then now I am, for that I o≈ø≈øend ≈øome ≈øo much, that this poore booke could not find a pre≈ø≈øe until the ≈øoarings were a little clipped: and if by my expre≈ø≈øions and confe≈ø≈øions which I ≈øhal then lay open to your Maje≈øtyes judgement, I≈øhal not irritate your di≈øplea≈øure, but merit your gracious pardon, it wil engage mee too make the greater di≈øcovery es, which I ≈øhal for beare to any what ever but my owne Prince. But thus much I ≈øhal pre≈øume on in the interim, that your Maje≈øty be cautions of ≈øome neare you, and then feare not tho≈øe farre from you.

And let this be a cave at to the Dutch, for no que≈øtion if it be po≈ø≈øibly to corrupt any of there greate≈øt States, which God for bid tho≈øe of We≈øtmin≈øter wil not be wanting to the ut mo≈øt of there endeavours and ≈øtocks (which England with greife may ≈øay) are to great. attempts but; to ≈øuch nobility, and ≈øuch councellours I conclude thus (which I de≈øire may be a caveat to the remaining hone≈øt of Lords and privy councellors) that greatne≈ø≈øe can not exempt them from the vengeance of God, nor al the wealth in the Parliaments trea≈øury bye them there from, which commandement (contrary to there knowledge and con≈øcience that they ≈øhould honour God and be true to ther King) they doe thus pre≈øumptuou≈øly tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe; which is neither Gods commandement cannot deterre, nor Gods Word advi≈øe them, nor his judgements feare them, I wil ≈øay as Saint John writes in the 12. But he hold and read there petition pre≈øented to his Maje≈øty (whom they wilfully murthered) on the 16. day of Iuly 1642. there you ≈øhal find that the≈øe u≈øurpers then called God of heaven and earth to witne≈ø≈øe that they would defend his Maje≈øty from all harmes, and dangers, etc. and that they would confirme your, lawes, and redeeme your lo≈øt liberties, veiw likewi≈øe his Maje≈øtyes reply to this petition, that he ≈øhould not count him≈øelfe ≈øafe until they had layd downe there armes, and delivered up his townes and magazines, which they detained from him, and that the tumults of London were ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed, then veiw the replication of the≈øe now u≈øurpers to that replication dated the 29. of Iuly. That they de≈øired his then Maje≈øty to accept of this there ju≈øt reply, that they could not di≈øcharge the tru≈øt repo≈øed in them, for the ≈øafety of the King, and Kingdome (marke that country men King and Kingdome) neither could they yeeld to the≈øe demands of his Maje≈øtyes, for (≈øay they in that replication) they tooke up armes, and
the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of ≈øuch townes and maguzines, for the ≈øecurity of religion the ≈øafety of his Maje≈øtyes per≈øon, of the Kingdome and Parliament all which they ≈øaw to be in mo≈øt eminent danger. (Marke againe al the≈øe re≈øolutions) and there in they likewi≈øe de≈øire that the King would returne to his court af whitehal, a≈ø≈øuring him that his royal per≈øon ≈øhould be as ≈øafe there, as in any other place (they having a≈ø≈øurance of the loyalty of the city of London to his Maje≈øty, and to that purpo≈øe they have taken care to prevent al danger which his Maje≈øty may ju≈øtly apprehend. (Countrymen) by this petition, and the 2. replications with the order of Parliament made there on, Die Iovis Iul. 30. 1642. ordered by the Lords a≈ø≈øembled in Parliament, that the petition and replication of the Lords and Commons be printed and publi≈øhed, and that they be read by the par≈øons and curates in al churches of England and Wales. Iohn Browne Cl. Parl.

I could give you many more of there declarations remon≈øtrances, engagements, prote≈øtations, nay there oaths, and Covenants, where in they have ≈øolemnly ≈øworne to maintaine the King in his ju≈øt priveledges, and to pre≈øerve the per≈øon honour and dignity of the King with there lives and fortunes and that they would maintaine the ju≈øt liberties and Freedomes of the people.

But now let an inquiry be made, if the≈øe u≈øurpers you fight for, have done and performed the lea≈øt part of this replication, or any of theire remon≈øtrances &c. & fir≈øt let is inquire what they have acted as to religion. Which they.

1. Have not only lacerated and tourne to peeces the fundamentals thereof, but they have quite aboli≈øhed and wholely extirpated the very rootes and branches therof. Have they not in there very night marches (in which they were conducted by the wofull light of Burning townes) few making re≈øi≈øtance al being a≈øtoni≈øhed at the prodigy thereof
≈øeeing the churches them≈øelves polluted with hor≈øes and even committing bea≈øtly acts therein, virgins with rapes, and the cryes of the churchmen heard louder, and farther then the drummes, and trumpets of tho≈øe you maintaine, ≈øeeing the pollution of holy things thus trampled upon, nay holy and godly mini≈øters impri≈øoned and turned out from there ≈øtockes, and (that not al) but put to death for preaching the word of God according to there con≈øciences, and this being done have they not put in anabipti≈øtical, ≈øchi≈ømatical fellowes, doe they not ≈øuffer your pulpits to be adulterated by coblers, tinkers, weavors &c. Who teaceth nothing but ≈øedition con≈øpiracy, fal≈øe doctrine and Here≈øy from which good Lord in his due time deliver you.

2. Next let us make an inquiry concerning the Kings per≈øon and dignity, which they have ≈øo often called God to witne≈ø≈øe and other imprecations in there printed acts (but di≈ø≈øembled deeds) that they de≈øired God to deale by them & theres, as they dealt by his then Maje≈øty and progeny, which God grount.

I ≈øay (Countrymen) let us inquire if they have not (in ≈øtead of maintaining him in his royal dignityes) impri≈øoned his ≈øacred per≈øon, and in ≈øtand of pre≈øerving his royal life if they have not wilfully murthered him in a mo≈øt ignominious way, as you already heard, and in ≈øtead of making his Crownes to flouri≈øh upon him & his po≈øterity, they have ≈øold them to Gold≈ømiths, and aboli≈øhed his po≈øterity for ever ≈øo farre as in them lyes, and this was there cheife≈øt aimes of there fir≈øt taking up armes.

3. Thirdly enquire after your freedomes and liberties (deare Countrymen) behold whom you made as Gods among≈øt you, have they not ≈øacrifized your bloods to there fortunes, doe they not drive you on, upon al occa≈øions in the front of battles and ≈øtormes, as ≈øheepe to the ≈ølaughter. What navyes mu≈øt be prepared, what armies rai≈øed, what
warres pro≈øecuted, what cities de≈øtroyed, nations depopulated on the only effects of there opinions, and none of al this again≈øt Heathens or antichri≈øtian enemies; but even again≈øt there owne fellow ≈øubjects, and neighbouring prote≈øtant bretheren, with whom there ever was firme league until ≈øuch ≈øycophants came to be rulers over you.

Mu≈øt they not be judges and Iuries of your bloods; fortunes, behaviours, and e≈øtimations? wil they not utter thinges according to the dictates of there owne affections? doe they not mea≈øure al things by the circle of there owne advantages? have they not made your publicke plentyes quitt the preheminence to there private profits? have they not made al that is yours ≈øerviceble to there amplitude; in a word, have they not ≈øacrifized your blood and fortunes to there arbitrary wils, and have they not effu≈øed blood in the≈øe warres at no rate and cheri≈øhed devi≈øions purpo≈øely to purcha≈øe what they have obtrined hitherto, to be Kings and emperours, over you, in trea≈øuring up va≈øt ≈øummis of monyes from you, re≈øolving to leape into an authority of a more hopeful permanency; and have not you brought this upon your ≈øelves by ≈øighting for and ri≈øing with them upon al occa≈øions; but goodne≈ø≈øe for bid that ≈øuch earthtly wormes ≈øhould continue over you after ≈øuch a manner as they have done in making there progre≈ø≈øes through ≈ømoaking cities, & over the trampled bodies of halfe dead men, and continuing in the exhau≈øting al that is yours, rather then they ≈øhould be exhau≈øted.

O countrymen looke but upon there waies a little better and take the length of this my pro≈øpective gla≈ø≈øe, and you ≈øhal perceive, that they know if the admini≈øtration of the publicke ≈øhould be regulated according to the lawes of God, by the judgement of a pious and godly Prince, then they mu≈øt become ba≈øe, low, and mo≈øt contemptible,
that they ≈øhould be expo≈øed to prey and direption.

They are neither like the heathens a as Hannibal who ≈øayd, Miles parce ferro? and Marcellus, wi≈øhing he could quench the flames of burning Syracu≈øa) no they de≈øire not to bye peace at ≈øo deare a rate, nor ≈øell there dominations ≈øo cheape, neither would they immitate Tytus (lyfting up his hands and eyes to heaven) wept over the Carka≈ø≈øes of the Iewes. No, they chu≈øe rather to ≈øtrutte it out with pride, and make them≈øelves inebriate with pa≈ø≈øion, and ≈øtrengthen there fury with de≈øolation, nought but in exorable wrathes cohabite with there di≈øloyal mindes. But let them be≈øure that our merciful Lord, wil be offended with the long continuance and the≈øe la≈øting malignityes of there undertakings, they having cea≈øed to be what they profe≈ø≈øed long ≈øince, they have forgone there declared innocence, and in ≈øtead of increa≈øing in reputation of godline≈ø≈øe and a good cau≈øe (which they then pretended to have in hand) they have built up there towers of fury and malice again≈øt al goodne≈ø≈øe, both as concerning your religion and e≈øtates (nothing at al e≈øteeming of what our ≈øaviour ≈øayd) when he commanded al ≈øcandals to be remooved from religion and out of the temple of the Lord dooming a Mil≈øtone to be hanged about there neckes and ca≈øt into the ≈øea, and nothing e≈øteeming of another rule of our ≈øaviours, love they neibour as they ≈øelfe.

I mu≈øt tel you countrymen the gentiles in times pa≈øt were amazed at the charity of Chri≈øtians, to ≈øee how they loved each other but now the heathens, behold among≈øt Chri≈øtians brother again≈øt brother, father again≈øt Sonne, de≈øtroying on another, and butchering each other, pro≈øecuting, and per≈øecuting on another with endle≈ø≈øe hatred, which can not be but a ≈øad Harmony in the greate≈øt of there Iubilations; now for al the≈øe things are dayly ≈øeene by you, yet you wil cleave to the≈øe mon≈øters of mankind, you have hitherto
rather chu≈øed to peri≈øh with them, then to live a godly, quiet, and a ≈øober life, under your King the cho≈øen on of God.

O countrymen I be ≈øeech you by the mercies of God and in the bowels of Ie≈øus Chri≈øt, to for≈øake the≈øe rulers (who have for≈øaken God and you, the≈øe devourers of holine≈ø≈øe, who have enough to be≈øtow on there owne edifices but nothing to be≈øtow on the repairing the Temples of God, but rather pulling downe the churches as they doe dayly among≈øt you reedifiing there owne buildings, as it is in Agge the 1. and the 4. ver≈øe. It is time for your ≈øelves to dwell in your hou≈øes and this hou≈øe to lye wa≈øte.

O ≈øuch wretched cormorants, who doe not onely let the hou≈øes of God liewa≈øte, but utterly pul them downe, and purcha≈øe lands with the ≈øpoyles thereof, yet the≈øe ≈øacrilegious per≈øons are accounted by you good Chri≈øtians, yet you ≈øticke and adhere to them who make there buildings as it is ≈øpoken in the 6. chap. of Io≈øhua and the 26. ver≈øe. Not laying the foundations thereof in the blood of there bodyes, but in the ≈øpoyle of there ≈øoules, which God in the conclu≈øion wil make them as ≈øwallowes ne≈øts, which in the winter fall downe of them≈øelves: and wil you yet thinke upon ≈øuch people, wil you ≈øtil, deny your obedience to your King, who would there on doe as Noah did after the ≈øtood who built an alter to the Lord Gen. the 8. and the 20. ver≈øe.

I wil here conclude deare countrymen with this my la≈øt advi≈øe to thee. Which is. That thou for≈øake this pretended Parliament who have brought thee to this mi≈øerable condition that they have left no authority in England able to ≈øettle peace; your lives & fortunes being liable to there lu≈øtful wils by illegal accu≈øations blanke impeachments, threatning declarations who have put out the eyes of the Kingdome (the two univer≈øities of Oxford & Cambridge) knowing that learning is a ≈øteppe to Religion, & both to your lawes & liberties,
and al enemies to there barbarons, irrational and illegal way of Government, al which when you tooke part fir≈øt with the≈øe members, wee that have Chri≈øtianity doe beleive that you were ≈øeduced by the≈øe faire pretences of defending Religion, King, lawes, and liberties, which they fir≈øt held to you; and you thereby being unwilling to have a Parliament conquered by the ≈øword and con≈øequently your ≈øelves, and you not thinking that they could ≈øo farre prevaricate as to con≈øpire again≈øt King, Parliament, and your ≈øelves, to the utter ≈øubver≈øion of al lawes, liberties, and the fundamental Government of the Land, betraying religion unto Heretickes, and Schi≈ømatikes, ≈øharing the ≈øpoyles of 3. Kingdomes betweene them, & now re≈øolving to enrich them≈øelves more in forraigne Lands, I ≈øay that (as my ≈øelfe was once at the fir≈øt blinded) you my countreymen had no intention they ≈øhould be ≈øo farre intru≈øted as you have found to your greife they have engaged you before you were aware: (but thinke it not yet too late to draw backe your feet, and yet ≈øtippe the bridle out of your mouthes, with which bit they thinke they have you at there checke, having girt the ≈øaddle ≈øo fa≈øt to your galled backes, and they as ranke riders mounted, who have not only ≈øpurred you out of your e≈øtates, lawes; and liberties, but wil ≈øpurre you into hel by new oathes, Trea≈øons, Covenants, &c. If you take not the more heed, and be not the more re≈øolute, for now they have Squeezed what they can out of the Kings party, they cal them home, beginning to make up there bottomele≈ø≈øe ve≈ø≈øels ful out of your e≈øtates who have beene there freinds.

Now I have ≈øhewed you the Lyon whome they hunted after (the Lord of the forre≈øt) not only to be ≈øicke and weake and ≈øo become a prey to them, he is not only goared by the oxe, bitten by madd doggs, and kicked by A≈ø≈øes, and as our ≈øaviour was ≈øpittedon by phari≈øes, but even as our ≈øaviour was become a prey and cru≈øified for our ≈øinnes, ≈øo was
your King for your lawes liberties, and the ≈øinnes of the whole three Kingdomes.
Now to al Chri≈øtian Princes I ≈øpeake to you e≈øpecially of blood or the ≈øame religion which this martired King Charles the, fir≈øt was.

Looke I ≈øay (you neibouring Kings and Princes) upon this ≈øad example, unheard of Pre≈øident, and unparelled violence, and the Lord graunt you may apply it to your owne ≈øoules, and lay your councels and forces in conjunction to make examples of ≈øuch murtherous ≈øubjects, thereby you ≈øhal not only feare your owne people from the like attempt but ree≈øtabli≈øh him who no doubt may be able to helpe any of your greatne≈ø≈øes in ≈øuch or any other di≈øtre≈ø≈øe, and I am confident wil be willing to his utter mo≈øt power. And you wil have (O Princes) the hearts and praiers of al our gracious Kings leidge people in his three Kingdomes of England Scotland and Ireland, for your redemption of them likewi≈øe from ≈ølavery and bondage, to which I cry. Amen.

div.head: THE EPILOGUE.
And declaration of the penman.
div.p: TO ≈øhew your gracious Maje≈øty that I love my country ≈øo much that I could devote my ≈øelfe to death for it as the Decij in Rome have done and that I re≈øolve to be ≈øuch, Quem neque pauperies, neque mors, neque vincula terrent; I (in the pre≈øence of God and in the name of al the freeborne commoners of England) doe declare, that there is no legal Parliament in England nor lawful Government in Scotland and Ireland, that there is not 495. Commoners by names of Knights and Burge≈ø≈øes neither is there a hou≈øe of Lords, nor is there a King with out any of which by the knowne lawes of England, petition of right by which Kings formerly knew what was theres, and the ≈øubjects theres, nor by there ordinances remon≈øtrances and declarations made in the yeares 1642. 1643. where in they declared they intended not, neither could they make law without his them Maje≈øtyes con≈øent; I doe farther prote≈øt again≈øt tho≈øe arbitrary, exacting, and u≈øurping few members remaining at We≈øtmin≈øter, that what ever they have done, or ≈øhal doe, as thay now are, is void, and null by law ab initio, and of none of effect by there owne doctrines, and judgements declared in there ordinance made by them the 20. of Augu≈øt 1647. where in they made void ab initio al votes, ordinances, and orders, pa≈ø≈øed by the then Lords and Commons from the 26. of Iuly 1647. to the 6. of Augu≈øt following, when there ≈øpeaker with ≈øome other renegadoes of them huried away to the army then at Wind≈øor, and this faith I re≈øolve to live and die in as
